What I look for in a landscape tripod For the kind of landscape work I do ‚Äì seascapes, woodland, long exposures and changeable light ‚Äì my tripod needs to: Stay rock solid in wind and on uneven ground Reach a comfortable eye-level height without a centre column Go very low for foreground-driven compositions Handle heavier lenses with a good safety margin Allow precise composition without constant fiddling I‚Äôll use that lens to compare the heads and legs. In practice that means: You use the ball to make big moves quickly ‚Äì for example, swinging from portrait to landscape or re-aiming to a new composition. Once you‚Äôre close, you use the geared knobs on pitch and roll to nudge the framing by small, precise increments. So you get some of the speed of a ball head with much of the precision of a geared head, which is very appealing for landscape photography where horizons and fine adjustments matter. The trade-off is that not every axis is geared. Panning (yaw) is still a free-moving, non-geared rotation at the base, whereas on the GD3WH every axis is driven by a geared knob. Coming from the older head, I often found my hand reaching for a geared control that simply isn‚Äôt there. My experience with the GD36PT in the field I really enjoyed the feel of the geared movement on the GD36PT. It‚Äôs smooth, positive and very satisfying when you‚Äôre levelling the horizon or lining up foreground elements precisely. However, there are two important limitations to be aware of: Limited geared pitch range You only get a relatively small amount of geared travel forwards and backwards (pitch). To go beyond that, you have to loosen the ball and re-set the head, then come back to the gears for fine tuning. That‚Äôs workable, but slower than a full-range geared head when you‚Äôre making bigger compositional changes. Snagging on the tripod mounting plate The more serious issue for me is mechanical rather than conceptual. When I pitch the camera further forwards or backwards, the geared controls and housing can physically snag on the top mounting plate of the Mammoth tripod. The supplied spacer under the head just isn‚Äôt quite high enough ‚Äì it feels like it‚Äôs short by about 3 mm ‚Äì so there isn‚Äôt enough clearance between the outer body of the head and the tripod plate. In normal, near-level shooting positions the head is a pleasure to use. It‚Äôs when you push into steeper pitches ‚Äì which happens often in landscape photography when you‚Äôre shooting up a slope or down to foreground rocks ‚Äì that the snag becomes frustrating. By contrast, the GD3WH doesn‚Äôt suffer from this. It‚Äôs slower to work with overall, but the full geared range and extra physical clearance mean it feels more predictable when you‚Äôre working at the extremes. 3. Verdict ‚Äì is the Mammoth + GD36PT the best tripod for landscape photography? Putting it all together: As a set of legs, the Benro Mammoth TMTH44C is outstanding. For landscape photography it ticks almost every box: stability, height, very low shooting positions, and a bowl that makes levelling fast. I‚Äôd happily call it one of the best tripods for landscape photography in its class, especially for serious users who aren‚Äôt counting every gram. As a head, the Benro GD36PT is a more nuanced story. The hybrid concept works well and the geared motion is lovely to use within its range, but the limited pitch movement and the snagging on the tripod mounting plate mean it doesn‚Äôt fully replace my GD3WH for more extreme compositions.
